lines.text:
[singing to Mister Pain]
Poor Mother Hubbard, what would she do? I'm so broke I don't have a bone to throw at you.

[about the coffin]
There may be a mummy in there.
Oh mummy mummy, open up it's daddy.
I have a special delivery for you.
Special delivery, which is why you put it through the window instead of the letter box.

[seeing the robot]
It's me uncle Jerry-miah, they've canned him! And me without a tin opener in the whole house.

[singing]
I lift up my finger and I say tweet tweet, now now, shush shush, come come.

Scientist calling himself The Vampire is a man named Von Housen born in Bosnic in 1894. He is the descendant of Baron Von Housen whom legend immortalized as a vampire. For reasons of his own, Von Housen claims to be an earthly reproduction of his notorious ancestor, owing his continued existence to the consumption of human blood. Needless to say, there is not the faintest vestige of truth in his claim, but it does not deny that he is a scientist of considerable repute and his activities shall be restrained.

Personally, I feel that we are dealing with a dangerous character. Not for what he claims to be, but for what he is; a fanatical scientist with a stupid gang of men who have allowed themselves to be mesmerized by legend.
Did you say that you're from the Ministry?
Yes, that is right.
I did not know that they had foreigners in the British ministry.
Oh, my dear Miss Loretti, this is the foreign ministry.
Um, w-w-what does he do with his victims?
He drinks their blood.

[shudders]
Drinks their blood.
Every drop.
Every drop?
Every drop.
What a thirst.
Master.
Yes?

[referring to the "Dracula" outfit worn by Von Housen]
I'm curious to know why you always sleep in your evening clothes.
Really?
Yes, Master.

[laughing]
I was buried in them.
When I came in, I saw you looking at that painting. Do you like bats?
No, I hate them. They give me cold shivers up and down me brisket.
That's a great pity. That happens to be my brother.
I intend to build 50,000 robots.
Yes.
But how many have you built so far?
Uh, one.
Sleeps in a coffin? Don't be dark.
I tell you he does. I've seen it.
Where?
In his bedroom. He hasn't got a bed in there. He's only got a coffin.
Listen, my old aunt Agatha likes sleeping in a rocking chair. There's nothing usual about that. The old boy prefers a coffin, well that's his funeral.
[last lines]
This is the end.
[first lines]
There she is.
Turn the car on.
